unicode.value: Lydia's Two-Word Verbs Learning Center - Exercises Page
This website is an online practice site specially designed for Lydia's Two-Word Verbs Learning Center

主题
节
单元
Two-Word-Verb Exercises
Lydia’s Two-Word Verb Learning Center

Notes:

  • This exercise website was also created and designed by Lydia.
  • All practice questions on this website were created by Lydia.

Instructions: 

  • There are six different types of exercises on this website.
  • All of these questions are created to check how well you have comprehended the two-word verb demonstrated before and to help you practice how to use it.
  • Please complete each question carefully. Feedback can only be provided after you submit answers to all questions.
Text and Tasks
Exercise 1 (Easy) - Match Pairs - 10 Questions
Match Pairs
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Match the following two-word verbs with their meanings.

Note that STH means something; SB means somebody.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

C 1. come along A. (+ on) get involved in an exciting or profitable activity/opportunity
A 2. get in B. (+ to) succeed in reaching a physical destination or stage
E 3. come over  C. come in the area near STH/SB
J 4. go over D. be happening soon (esp. be broadcast soon)
H 5. take in E. come to a place or area (spot, room, town, country), esp. towards SB or to join SB
B 6. get through F. (+ to) reduce itself to one particular thing that is the most important or essential matter
D 7. come up G. remove STH that was previously put up or put in place
G 8. take down H. provide a place for SB to live or stay
I 9. get off I. manage to avoid serious trouble or consequences (esp. legal punishment)
F 10. come down J. move towards a place or person, esp. by crossing an area (room, city, country)
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

C 1. come along A. (+ on) get involved in an exciting or profitable activity/opportunity
A 2. get in B. (+ to) succeed in reaching a physical destination or stage
E 3. come over  C. come in the area near STH/SB
J 4. go over D. be happening soon (esp. be broadcast soon)
H 5. take in E. come to a place or area (spot, room, town, country), esp. towards SB or to join SB
B 6. get through F. (+ to) reduce itself to one particular thing that is the most important or essential matter
D 7. come up G. remove STH that was previously put up or put in place
G 8. take down H. provide a place for SB to live or stay
I 9. get off I. manage to avoid serious trouble or consequences (esp. legal punishment)
F 10. come down J. move towards a place or person, esp. by crossing an area (room, city, country)

1. come along A. (+ on) get involved in an exciting or profitable activity/opportunity
2. get in B. (+ to) succeed in reaching a physical destination or stage
3. come over  C. come in the area near STH/SB
4. go over D. be happening soon (esp. be broadcast soon)
5. take in E. come to a place or area (spot, room, town, country), esp. towards SB or to join SB
6. get through F. (+ to) reduce itself to one particular thing that is the most important or essential matter
7. come up G. remove STH that was previously put up or put in place
8. take down H. provide a place for SB to live or stay
9. get off I. manage to avoid serious trouble or consequences (esp. legal punishment)
10. come down J. move towards a place or person, esp. by crossing an area (room, city, country)

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Answer Key

1. C

2. A

3. E

4. J

5. H

6. B

7. D

8. G

9. I

10. F
Exercise 2 (Easy) - Fill in Blank - 10 Questions
Fill in the Blanks - 10 Questions
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Choose the correct form of a two-word verb from the box to replace the words in italics in the sentences below. Put the verbs in the correct tense.

    take in     work out     get up     turn off     put on          

 come along     take off     wake up     pay off     go out
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. She just paid off paid a debt in full for her car loan.

2. I woke up  stopped sleeping very early this morning.

3. She took off  removed her jacket as she came in.

4. I get up   stop sleeping and get out of bed at 7 o’clock during the week.

5. I put on donned a coat and left the house.

6. Don’t be taken in  deceived by his charm—he’s full of lies.

7. He went out  left the house for a social activity with some friends.

8. She works out  does physical exercise in the local gym every day.

9. Is the computer turned on? Will you turn it off  stop it working by pressing a button, please?

10. When the right opportunity comes along  appear, she’ll take it.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

1. She just paid off paid a debt in full for her car loan.

2. I woke up  stopped sleeping very early this morning.

3. She took off  removed her jacket as she came in.

4. I get up   stop sleeping and get out of bed at 7 o’clock during the week.

5. I put on donned a coat and left the house.

6. Don’t be taken in  deceived by his charm—he’s full of lies.

7. He went out  left the house for a social activity with some friends.

8. She works out  does physical exercise in the local gym every day.

9. Is the computer turned on? Will you turn it off  stop it working by pressing a button, please?

10. When the right opportunity comes along  appear, she’ll take it.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Answer Key

1. paid off

2. woke up

3. took off

4. get up

5. put on

6. taken in

7. went out

8. work out

9. turn it off

10. comes along
Exercise 3 (Medium) - Find Synonyms - 15 Questions
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Select the correct single-verb synonyms of two-word verbs from the dropdown box.

1. Bring up        raise

2. Carry on        continue

3. Come off       detach

4. Come out      release

5. Get on             enter

6. Go on              happen

7. Go down        decrease

8. Hang out         relax

9. Make up          constitute

10. Put off              postpone

11. Reach out        stretch

12. Set out            start

13. Set up            arrange

14. Take on          undertake

15. Take out        remove

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text that are key to understanding the concepts. These will probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Exercise 4 (Medium) - Multiple Choice - 15 Questions
Please choose the best answer to complete the sentenses below.
Enter the available choices here. You can add options by clicking the "Add Another Option" button. Delete options by clicking the red "X" next to the Option.
University of Auckland

Type in the feedback that you want the student to see when selecting the particular option. If you don't complete this box, eXe will automatically provide default feedback as follows: "Correct answer" as indicated by the selection for the correct answer; or "Wrong answer" for the other options.
Enter a hint here. If you do not want to provide a hint, leave this field blank.
Select the correct option by clicking on the radio button.

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

Exercise 5 (Hard) - Cloze Activity - 16 Questions
Cloze Activity
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Read the paragraph below. Choose the word from the word bank to fill in the missing word in each blank to complete the story. There are 16 blanks in the paragraph.

    take down       get off        go through      made up        get on     set off

       went off         kept on         took out         came up        reached out                       

     looked out      took off        come along      pick up         come out
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Last Christmas holiday, my husband, Li, (1) came up with the idea to (2) take our family down to Florida.

After discussion, we (3) made up our minds to go to Miami. My friends Yi and Yu would also

(4) come along with us. We planned to (5)  set off in the morning and meet my friends at the airport.

On the way to the airport, our car’s fuel level alarm (6) went off . Then, I realized that I had left my cell phone

at home, so we drove back to (7) pick up the phone. When we arrived at the airport, we had just enough time to

(8) go through passport and security check and (9) get on  the plane. The plane (10) took off shortly,

and the view was breathtaking from the upper sky. I (11) looked out the window to enjoy it. A toddler

in my back row (12) kept on  crying because of the high air pressure. I (13) took out a cookie from

my bag, and he (14)  reached out for it and stopped crying. When we landed in Miami, we couldn’t  

(15) get off  the plane because there was a problem on the runway. After waiting for 30 minutes, we were

finally allowed to (16) come out of the plane.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

After discussion, we (3) made up our minds to go to Miami. My friends Yi and Yu would also

(4) come along with us. We planned to (5)  set off in the morning and meet my friends at the airport.

On the way to the airport, our car’s fuel level alarm (6) went off . Then, I realized that I had left my cell phone

at home, so we drove back to (7) pick up the phone. When we arrived at the airport, we had just enough time to

(8) go through passport and security check and (9) get on  the plane. The plane (10) took off shortly,

and the view was breathtaking from the upper sky. I (11) looked out the window to enjoy it. A toddler

in my back row (12) kept on  crying because of the high air pressure. I (13) took out a cookie from

my bag, and he (14)  reached out for it and stopped crying. When we landed in Miami, we couldn’t  

(15) get off  the plane because there was a problem on the runway. After waiting for 30 minutes, we were

finally allowed to (16) come out of the plane.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Answer key

1. came up

2. take down

3. made up

4. come along

5. set off

6. went off

7. pick up

8. go through

9. get on

10. took off

11. looked out

12. kept on

13. took out

14. reached out

15. get off

16. come out
Exercise 6 (Hard) - Mini Dialogues - 16 Questions
Mini Dialogues
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Complete each conversation with a two-word verb from the box. There are six mini dialogues in this exercise. There are either two or three missing words in each conversation.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

take up     come on     work out     reach out     look out     

 put up     hold on     go through     came out*2     got off     

 carry on     take in     figure out     break off     took out

Dialogue 1.

Lydia: Have you heard of the news that came out just recently?

Li: Yes! It was so shocking! I still can’t take it in .   

Lydia: Same here. I can’t imagine what he had gone through . 


Dialogeu 2.

Lydia: Hi Hudson, did you get that job at Y Company?

Hudson: No…… I came out poorly in the job interview because I wasn’t well prepared.

Lydia: Don’t worry. You could take up the offer from X Company.


Dialogue 3.

Lydia: It’s not right that he got off with just a small fine and left the court! I can’t figure out

what the judge and jury were thinking!

Li: I can’t agree with you more! I can never put up with injustice!


Dialogeu 4.

Lydia: I’m sorry to break off you in the mid-sentence. Please hold on a minute.

Li: What happened?

Lydia: It’s just too noisy here to carry on conversations with you. I’ll find somewhere quiet to talk to you. 


Dialogue 5.

Li: Come on , don’t be shy and share the love story of you and your boyfriend with us!

Lydia: It’s a cliché. We met at our mutual friend’s birthday party. And he took me out for dinner

several times.


Dialogue 6.

Li: I’m sorry that you and your boyfriend didn’t work out eventually. You know you can reach out to me

anytime when you want to talk.

Lydia: Thanks, Li. I think we’re fine. We still look out for each other like family.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Answer Key

1. came out

2. take in

3. gone through

4. came out

5. take up

6. got off

7. figure out

8. put up

9. break off

10. hold on

11. carry on

12. come on

13. took out

14. work out

15. reach out

16. look out
